'''Andy Coogan''' (born 1917) is a Scottish [[author]], [[World War II]] veteran and former middle-distance runner.
==Biography== Born in Glasgow, the oldest child of poor Irish immigrants,<ref name="book">{{cite web|url=http://www.rbooks.co.uk/product.aspx?id=1780575696|title=''Tomorrow You Die: The Astonishing Survival Story of a Second World War Prisoner of the Japanese'' by Andy Coogan, Graeme Ogilvy |publisher=Mainstream Publishing|accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref> Coogan's promising athletic career was interrupted by the outbreak of World War II. As a young man, he was a [[mile run]]ner and his goal was to compete in the [[Olympic Games]] for Great Britain, but the terrible consequences of war and imprisonment left him physically unable to continue this pursuit.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/cycling/9349989/London-2012-Olympics-Great-uncle-Andy-is-inspiration-for-Sir-Chris-Hoy-to-carry-Olympic-torch-in-Manchester.html|title=Great Uncle Andy is Inspiration for Sir Chris Hoy to carry Olympic Torch in Manchester|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref>
Captured during the [[Fall of Singapore]], Coogan was interned at the Changi camp (site of the modern day [[Changi Prison]]) before being transported to [[Taiwan]], where he worked as a slave in a copper mine and was twice ordered to dig his own grave. He was later sent to Japan on a [[hell ship]] voyage that nearly killed him.
After the war, Coogan returned to Scotland and founded Tayside Amateur Athletic Club, competing in veteran athletics, coaching, and devoting himself to encouraging everyone in the community to participate in sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.london2012.com/torch-relay/torchbearers/torchbearers=andrew-coogan-6790/ |title=London 2012 Official Site|publisher=London2012.com|accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref>
In August 2012, [[Mainstream Publishing]] published Coogan's autobiography ''Tomorrow You Die: The Astonishing Survival Story of a Second World War Prisoner of the Japanese'' - the story of his 'poverty-stricken boyhood in the slums of the Gorbals to the atomic wasteland of Nagasaki'.<ref name="book" />
==Personal life== Coogan is the great-uncle of six-time [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] champion [[Chris Hoy]].<ref name="telegraph" />
==London 2012 Olympic torch relay== On 12 June 2012, Coogan took part in the [[2012 Summer Olympics torch relay]]. Nominated to be one of 8,000 torchbearers by Hoy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2012-08-07/meet-the-man-who-inspired-chris-hoy-to-become-an-olympic-hero|title=Meet the Man Who Inspired Chris Hoy to become an Olympic Hero|publisher=Radiotimes.com|accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref> Coogan carried the flame on a leg near [[Dundee]] - to 'raptuous applause' from the watching public.<ref name="telegraph" />
==''Tomorrow You Die''== Coogan's memoir was published on 23 August 2012. It was well received at the [[Edinburgh International Book Festival]], with ''[[The Scotsman]]'' hailing the event as one of 'those when can you forget it’s anything at all to do with the selling of books. Instead, it’s just you listening to someone telling stories that go straight from their heart into yours. So it was with Mr Coogan'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/books/features/interview-will-self-author-of-umbrella-1-2491042|title=Interview|newspaper=[[The Scotsman]]|accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref>
